comments.commentBody: I don't boil the cabbage. I cook the sausage stove top in a Dutch oven with a little prosciutto and garlic then toss in cabbage, before throwing it in the oven uncovered to brown. Speeds up the process with the same results. Love this dish.

Not at all. I accidentally cooked a turkey at 475 last Thanksgiving and no one complained, and several complemented the taste and moistness. My adult sisters would have had not trouble critiquing it. The NPR cooking show Splended Table also instructed that "high and fast" is an optional way to roast a bird.
https://www.splendidtable.org/recipes/lynnes-fast-and-crisp-roast-turkey...
I make NYT Mississippi Roast recipe using pork shoulder instead of beef, then I make this recipe with the leftover meat and use canned hominy. It's so so good!
Excellent dish with a nice balance of flavors. If you've making it with something that needs some sauce, like rice, then double the honey-mustard sauce
Hew? Wee? Really?

This is the best comment that I have read in the NYT. The writer should expanded into an open editorial and the Times should published it.
Many times, when I read an article about issues like this one, I get the impression that the NYT writer is copying and pasting about one half of the article from prior articles without really trying to make an effort of researching the subject in a more deep historical context. So whatever someone said five or ten years ago keep showing up. No wonder about the current state of journalism in America.

Thank you. I have been writing to newspapers about this issue for decades and they still fail to properly report it. It's of the utmost importance for journalists to do their research and not become propaganda mouthpieces for governments and demagogues.

It's disturbing to read lines such as "in 1949, when Taiwan split from China". As you point out, the KMT, led by the brutal dictator Chiang Kai-Shek, split from China and fled to Taiwan then. The Taiwanese people were already there and had a separate identity. What followed was decades of oppression, brutality, and attempts to wipe out their culture.

In dealing with an issue that so many Americans seem in the dark about, it would behoove the Times to write an article discussing this history. In an era of fake news and poor awareness of facts, journalists from all outlets should heed this call to inform the public of the real story.

But the most important piece is that Taiwan is rather happy not be a part of PRC without any hostility. The US pursued independence from Britain, which didn't "allow it" either. You are blurring the questions.

As a young Taiwanese myself who participated the Sunflower Movement, I believe Taiwanese identity and economy are both the reasons why so many young people join the movement.

Service industrial workforce in Taiwan which would be impacted greatly by the service trade pact is consisted about 70% of total workforce, and the former government could not provide reasonable supporting measures for the impacts. This is unquestionable the main motivation behind the majority who join the movement.

However, Taiwanese identity is definitely another drive behind the movement. Ever since former President Ma won the election back in 2008, the pride of Taiwanese people had been trampled underfoot by both China and KMT governments. Can you imagine that you are not allowed to show your national flag on your own soil? But yes, this kind of incidents happened not just once, but numerous times back in 2008~2014. Of course many Taiwanese will be agitated by such insults.

Last but not least, I don't think DDP had anything to do with Sunflower movement... Just look at the largest and most successful protest organized by DPP at its prime back in 2005 against the anti-secession law, there are only 270 thousand protesters in Taipei City, but on March-30 rally during Sunflower movement, there are more than 400-500 thousand people. Just please don't get confused between political hitchhiking and masterminding...

That the US's vaunted "exceptionalism" is in decline is indisputable. The tragedy, sadly, is that it's avoidable. America continues to confound observers in her penchant for self-destruction. "A great civilization is not conquered from without until it has destroyed itself within".
By abandoning the core values of "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness" for ALL, as envisioned by her Founding Fathers, she’s unwittingly undermined her legitimacy. Power without legitimacy is tyranny. And increasingly, this has come to characterise America for many through her role in myriad geopolitical conflicts, recurrent global financial crises, impoverishment of her own citizens, gross inequality, rampant individualism/Darwinism, corruption and unrestrained greed as epitomised by corporations, etc.
Ominously, the recent outrageous elections in America may hasten her demise. China understands that anarchy/partisanship diminishes nationhood. Contrast this to the solidarity and focus of the CCP, "elected" or not.
To remain relevant, and perhaps regain her clout on the global stage, America must champion justice for ALL, domestically and internationally, by re-embracing the principles of "the common good" and “live and let live”. Thus respect is won.
She can’t bully her way to prominence. That era is gone! Obama understands this, hence his foreign policy strategy of seeking strength by promoting respect for others, without blunting the aura of America’s military might.
Gunpowder actually came from Assam, India.  Read Gates' (a British Historian) book on History.

The early demise of America and the American might is much exaggerated!  When a nation, like the US, can talk so profusely about its problems only, it is a sign that there is inherent strength in the system to overcome the manifest and latent drawbacks.  In short, America will remain the First for a long long time, may be become the First Among Equals toward the end of this century.
Only if we still have the freedom to talk about it critically.  I rather think Trump will try to curtain free speech next year.
You do know that lobbyist Bob Dole arranged that phone call, don't you?
And they're not wrong.

That is your supposition but the Chinese while not free of racial views have little trouble with black as an identifier. Their choice of date is based on the 2008 Financial Crises where the western economies collapsed and some have yet to recover and China’s own quick recovery. They take this as an indication of ideological superiority when it could as well be attributed to Keynesian intervention.

Why do so many people read into Xi's daughter studying at Harvard as a contradiction of US decline? Harvard continues to be a top educational institution.

Additionally, decline doesn't mean overnight collapse. Oxford and Cambridge continue to be top global Universities and Great Britain, has arguably, been in decline since the Second Boer War.

The funny thing is that despite having all that intellectual advantage, the west, and especially america is struggling to keep up. None of the brightest economists predicted the financial meltdown of 2008 and west is constantly repeating the same mistakes in middle east, not to mention the enormous deficit spending of their central governments on things like social welfare and economic regulations.

China is fully functional and solute with hardly any social polarization and free of media running amok. The debt in china are largely harmless since they are state money lent to the very same state. The only part america needs to catchup with china is corruption.

Oh no, the 21st century will be the century of authoritarianism. The decline of the west is not speculative, it is a hard fact. Btw i would love to see the return of korean military dictatorship, life was so much better back then: booming manufacturing economy and streets free of gangsters and pro north korean sympathizers.
The rich have homes in other towns, and money invested in the status quo.
The rich can hop on a plane to Sanya , Hainan to spend a smog free month on the beach .
Perhaps plutocrats and oligarchs are highly intelligent with respect to making money and pretty stupid about other matters.

Here's a great idea: Let's outsource our manufacturing to China! Not only can they pay workers pathetic wages, but they can also ravage the environment!

We'll call it "free trade" and we'll tell Americans that they will save a few dollars on all goods made in China.

Companies will pay little in tax, CEO salaries will explode, Americans will lose jobs, the environment we all ultimately share will be ruined, but other than that, what's not to like?

Um....no.

No one voted for Trump to bring jobs back by eliminating any clean air regulations.

Voters realize that off-shoring jobs to China and India exploit those workers AND ruin the global environment we all share. The only candidate who offered us a choice to stop this madness was Trump.

Manufacture here where rules are tougher and wages are higher. Get rid of the ridiculously nonsensical regulations. Meanwhile, prices will increase slightly. Consumers will pay more, but only what the market will bear. Corporations will be forced to roll back CEO pay. Inequality will lessen, which will burst the luxury bubble that drives up all costs.

Jeb and Hillary's business as usual will never be an option for career, self-serving politicians again.
They have a million reason$ to ignore the air pollution that comes with lucrative trade deals.  They spend very little time outside when they are actually in China.
